CD list
Monster Rancher Metropolis: The Cafe: Archived Topics From Prior Years: Year 2004 Topics (Year of the Venture): CD list
By Petit-Trot on Sunday, January 4, 2004 - 11:41 am:

I say we delete the CD lists. They take up too much space, take too much mod time and are practically useless. Either you have the CD or you don't, I seriously doubt people will start hunting for cds/dvds they don't already have. Most common monsters are obtainable from common cd/dvds, in-game saucer stones and combination/evolution. Sub-code data probably is or will be posted for the rarer monsters and for the oddities (like the all 25 monol).

A CD/DVD list is the most useless info this site will ever possess. It makes us look like amateurs.

By King952 on Sunday, January 4, 2004 - 02:10 pm:

I wouldn't say hunting, but if it's a 'recent' game or movie, I sure as heck might go out and rent it. If I know a friend who has that CD, I'll borrow it from him/her. I think that all though the CD list may be taking up quite a lot of mod time, it will take less time than having to redirect 20+ some posts of where to find a specific breed... Wouldn't you think so?

By Durahan2000 on Sunday, January 4, 2004 - 07:19 pm:

The monols are the walls right? Are there monols in MR4?

By GoldenBoy on Sunday, January 4, 2004 - 07:50 pm:

I disagree with you completely on this one PT, sorry.

1) King is correct about it causing more trouble than it
would solve. As it is, any QA queries can be answered with
a simple point to the archive. Without it, we'd have to
answer every request and then delete it after it was seen.

2) I don't see your point about it making us look like
amateurs. There is enough other content to dispel that
notion easily.

3) while the List itself may be of questionable importance,
it serves one really good purpose. It provides a simple, low
stress way for new members to contribute to the site. I feel
it is a great gateway forum for people, without the stress of
"hard research" It's a great way to play "look what i found"
without allowing brag posting.

I say keep the archive. Keep an eye on it for quality and
clarity, but don't delete it. Maybe a little more diligence
about locking off breeds that we have found "enough"
entries for, like I did for Henger on day 3 :|

By Petit-Trot on Sunday, January 4, 2004 - 09:47 pm:

That's exactly it. The only reasons we keep it is to shut newbies up and to give the illusion of contributing to the site. That's what I find pathetic and amateurish (trying to please even the lowest,laziest players). It doesn't help you build your ranch, doesn't make you a better breeder, it is useless data.

I also think a lot of the lists popping up in the MR4 section are superfluous. A lot of them are just descriptions easily found in-game.

By CHB on Monday, January 5, 2004 - 03:30 am:

I, for one, used the CD list just this week to find out if I owned a CD with a Raiden on it.

Lo and behold, I'm raising my Gargoyle now (Raiden/Naga).

Frankly, it just wouldn't seem like an Archive without a CD list, but I do agree about some of the lesser ones. Seriously, who is going to look in the CD list to find a Henger in MR4 or a Melon Suezo in MR2? :/

I think knocking the CD lists down to the locked breeds per each MR game would be best. Those are the monsters people have problems finding anyway, and if you go through the trouble of unlocking them, you'd certainly want to raise them. That way, when someone does find one of those CDs, they can still post the finding.

Of course, it would give us lots of free room for tourneys, cafe topics, just about anything else. With the encyclopedia in MR4, I'm going to go through all my CDs and DVDs anyway, regardless what's on what.

In the end, I got to back PT in the "Nobody cares about Mocchi CDs"

By Nate Railsback on Monday, January 5, 2004 - 10:17 am:

While some of the more common monsters may not need postings, remember that commonality can be an illusion to an individual poster. That is to say, you may get a lot of a certain monster, and think it to be pretty common, when other people are searching high and low for it. While I doubt anyone will lose sleep trying to find an MR4 Henger or an MR2 Melon Suezo, people HAVE asked for the MR4 Phoenix-- and I have about a dozen CDs that apparently make it (as that's the only thing I haven't unlocked yet and the game won't let me access them). It's also good for shorthand, in that I can quickly look at the CD lists and see what possible subtypes a monster can have, allowing me to plan my breeding programs better. Overall, I think it's very much worth it to keep the CD List around-- especially if Lisa thinks so, because she's the one paying for it all.

By Tristan Ferris on Monday, January 5, 2004 - 10:58 am:

I agree that once you have one of every monter you don't need a list to find the, you can mix them yourself, but as for the Rare monsters I would love to keep a list of those, for you may know someone who has this CD, DVD, or game and could borrow it or even rent it.

By CHB on Monday, January 5, 2004 - 01:11 pm:

Phoenix is also a rare monster, Nate, further backing my original point.

Common monsters are not as hard to find, and after you get one, you have the encyclopedia save so you don't have to worry about finding the CD again. After all, the most powerful monsters are combined from two powerful monsters themselves, so raising the father for your future champion won't matter if you use the CD or Encyclo.


After I unlock a breed, I'd like to know what CD its on, which is way, at the least, we should keep the locked monster CD lists for each game.

By Lao on Monday, January 5, 2004 - 11:16 pm:

I have always found the CD lists useful, even for MR4. I don't think that there has been a game yet that I didn't use it to nab rares or hard to find breeds (not always the "rare" ones). If list spam is a problem, lock the lists. But, not everyone has access to a CD burner.

By CHB on Tuesday, January 6, 2004 - 03:18 am:

And new CDs and DVDs come out everyday, Lao. In the long run, locking the list will make people only question why they are locked. And if we can't update the newest CD and DVD findings, because they are locked, then why have them in the first place.

I'll admit, different CD collections are in everyone's home. However, I think the difference between someone going and renting a DVD for a Phoenix and someone attempting to get a pure bred Pancho in the same fashion is quite self explanatory.

By Lao on Tuesday, January 6, 2004 - 04:23 am:

The difference isn't self-explanatory. From an in-game perspective, there's not much reason to prefer a Phoenix to a Dragon. A Beaclon also serves. Nor a Tiger to a Zuum. Pancho may seem like an easy target, but somebody out there likes them, and from a game perspective they're equivalent to a bunch of other monsters. I've always thought that Tigers were stupid, and they seem to be one of the series favorites. Point being, a Phoenix is not more important than a Pancho.

I'm advocating functional restraints, which are workable (list locks, merging all subs into a single breed list, whatever), instead of entirely dropping a resource which more people probably use than the FAQs, let alone the "non-amateurish" method building/maxing, etc.

This old breeder's opinion: keep the CD lists any way you can. They're far and away more useful than a lot of other things on here (monster/item description lists, tourney opponent stats, etc).

By MaskWormMaster on Tuesday, January 6, 2004 - 10:13 am:

From a CD List contributor perspective, I think the lists DO serve a valid purpose; Most of which has been stated in a few of the aforementioned posts. I would like to add one other thing in the realm of downsizing some of the space the Lists may be using. I've noticed several CD Listings that contain some unrelated dialog rather than the CD information. Also, in the reference to those Monsters that have a large access ratio (meaning there's more than 10 CDs that can generate it), perhaps a cut off at the 10th listing with an additional comment stating that there's no need for additional posts migh help. Perhaps if both of those sets of posts are deleted, a little more space may become available.

Just my MR.04 cents worth! J

By Hawkmoon on Tuesday, January 6, 2004 - 08:37 pm:

I've found the CD/DVD lists to be quite useful. Granted, my breeder experience is limited to MR3 and some MR4(just got it last week) so I'm probably considered an "amateur", but if I want to play a dragon NOW without going through 300 cds/dvds in the hopes of finding one, it's a great place to check to see if someone else found it in something I have already. Plus, since most listings seem to come from users personal collections, it's a way to get to know them. Someone's taste in music and other media says a lot about them.

By Kalach on Friday, January 9, 2004 - 06:08 am:

Gentleranchers, Good day.
Please allow me to introduce myself, by adding a slightly different direction to this discussion.

Up until this point, the question has been one of "Is the CD List really useful." And the discussion has been along the lines of:

Not really, it's too much trouble.

vs.

Yes, I find it useful.

With many gray areas in between.

As many are, I am of a middling opinion on this. I've yet to find a CD List where I had more that 4 of the CD's. (This was for MR2, but anyway..)

However... Let me suggest a different solution to the problem. I am a programmer, by profession, with some skill in the areas of database design and web interface creation. So what occurs to *me* is that someone could host a CD List off site from the discussion group, with a web interface to a DB.

Of course, what this solution needs is a place to host it. I have a small site, perhaps slightly smaller than this one, which I mostly use for the hosting of my email. I rarely do much with my bandwidth.

So what I would suggest is that myself (with semi-limited time) and a team of volunteers create an application by which the CD List can be moved outside of the boards, so the moderators do not have to deal with them. The boards could still have the CD List discussion group, with a pointer to the new app.

But, that's all just my two cents. If anyone has thoughts on the idea, they are begged to share them.

Kalach

By Lisa Shock on Friday, January 9, 2004 - 07:44 am:

Ever since we moved, people have suggested moving parts of the site to free servers, their own servers, free BBs systems, etc. So far, every one of those people has been around a while, then left -never to be heard from again. We have literally seen thousands of MR sites appear and fade away over the years, and tens of thousands of people have done the same.

And, of course, there is the stellar example of Ethel at DBW who ran the site for a few months then just left it, never cleaning up the bad entries that were posted before she went to an email only system, thus maintaining some of the worst 'information' online.

Then, of course, there's the constant risk to the site itself; in a nutshell the whole reason we are here in the first place, rather than our old, free home on LUSENET.

Actually doing this set up would take several things:
*several people willing to moderate it who have the ability to check in several times a day, every day (if you allow members to add their own posts -remember Josie's database with people entering obscenities daily? -or B's, where if he left for a couple days, porno would be posted in the CD list?)

*several people to process emails daily (if you run it like DBW was run, with submission via email)

*several people willing to monitor the user accounts, creating them, emailing people who have technical problems, getting rid of troublemakers

*someone to check on the site and software at least once a day, twice is preferrable.

The fact is, we have a very small group of people doing this already here. We simply don't have the resources to double our efforts for another site, unless you have a team with several hours a day free to work on it, every day, year-round.

By Kalach on Friday, January 9, 2004 - 09:20 am:

Glad to hear the voice of caution and wisdom. Let me clarify a few things:

#1 --> I would not host another forum/BB/whatever system. I actually have a small one tucked away that myself and friends use. I'm not interested in the headaches that I know you go through to maintain this. I am also not interested in presenting a site for discussion.

#2 --> You suggest that I will show up, provide the service and then disappear like so many others. I give me your guarantee that you are... likely right. I'm married, with a full time job, and trying to maintain some semblence of a social life. I cannot guarantee the time I can dedicate to maintaining user maintenance, etc. for a site like this.

#3 --> However, the site will be around. I currently pay for hosting, in order to have a mail server to host my domain. Why? Because I like having an email address: seth@corduan.net. It means a good much to me. The site will remain.

#4 --> I would rather someone much more dedicated than I to Monster rancher take care of the "oversite" account issues, such as they are. I am offering a site and some help in creating the application.

#5 --> I would assume that the userbase would be limited because this is the only place I would want the site to be publicized. I will not be submitting it to any search engines, etc... I would rather only people with verified accounts on this board be able to add CD information.

By Kalach on Friday, January 9, 2004 - 09:23 am:

Oh..

#6 --> I'm no board troll. This thread happened to coincide with my showing up. Lisa is kind of a community head, here, and if she doesn't feel right supporting the idea, then I bow to her wisdom.

By GoldenBoy on Friday, January 9, 2004 - 01:01 pm:

I had a nice long thoughtful post about all this on Jan5, that apparently I never actually posted. Ah well I am too sick and tired to come up with all of it again now. My main points boil down to this:

1) Can we keep this on topic? We are talking about the usefulness of the CD list, not the usefulness of all content on MRM or in the MR4 section.

2) Just because you personally don't find something useful doesn't mean someone else won't. Don't look at the transcriptions of ingame lists as the end of the project either. I know I plan to add and consolidate other info in those lists once the lists are complete.

3) Here's the big one and I want it answered well before I'll even entertain the notion of agreeing with removing a big section. What do you propose we replace it with? What in your mind is non amateurish? I hear a lot about getting rid of things, but no options given for what would replace them. The work that is being put up is the work that people want and have time to contribute to. If you have a better idea then get to work on it and post it!

By GoldenBoy on Friday, January 9, 2004 - 02:39 pm:

Feel free to elaborate PT, because as long as your argument
boils down to "I think the CD list is silly, and I don't want it
around any more" Then I am not buying it.

This is becoming an argument on what makes a good
website which is fine by me. I feel that the CD List makes us
more accessible to all ranchers. I think it keeps them
around and more likely to learn more about MR. I think it
makes good content, and to get rid of it would leave a big
gaping hole that would need to be filled.

I don't think MRM needs to concern ourselves with how
amateurish it looks, because umm if you hadn't noticed this
is a game PT. Last I checked, Lisa wasn't sending out check
every week so we can safely say we are amateurs.

I think I can safely say that MRM is a site about all aspects
of a game. Generation by CD is something that people put
a lot of research into. I can't see how it makes sense to
have all our advanced info about CD creation, without a CD
list to build upon. Someone who knows nothing of the
process can post a CD in the archive. Then someone who
knows and cares about burning CDs can find a copy of that
disc, post the subcode info and the MR community
benefits.

I also think you have ignored one simple and important
fact. There are a lot of people who set themselves the goal
of getting every monster. The CD list is quite helpful in that
pursuit.

By torey luvullo on Friday, January 9, 2004 - 03:21 pm:

actually this is a good discussion.

i am in total agreement with pt that a cd list is useless. since mr3, i don't keep them myself. in mr4, i don't need one. i shrined a bunch of discs in my first day, to learn breeds and breed name for building of the board. i don't even play that save; i play a different one with very few monsters entered.

at the same time, i would find it hard to believe that a full-service mr site would ever eliminate a cd list. too many people still enjoy - almost as a game in itself - what discs make what monsters. in every mr game, about 25-50% of the breed/subbreed possibilities are not rare, but don't come on all that many discs.

remember the search for the cowbird. those lists helped new searchers with a basic text of what not to search. it also gave them a place to record interesting results, in sections where not many entries existed.

so i never use them - i don't even post in them, cuz no one else would ever encounter the music i like. but i vote they stay.

By Petit-Trot on Friday, January 9, 2004 - 05:19 pm:

OK, I'm home now and can elaborate my answer. I'm not sure how this post will work out yet, but I apologize in advance if it feels like I am belittling some people.

Let's start by describing one of my daily visits on Gamefaqs. I see a post entitled "Oh my god...". Against my better judgement, I will sometimes click on it. And as I expected, it reads as something like this:"...have you seen that monster in c-class he's so cool where can i find it!!!". My reply, almost never posted, is:"Shrine some disks or play the game you idiot". I could, like many people do, tell him he should look at MRM's disk list. But I fear both answers will bring the same results. He will be out there shrining disks until he finds that monster. A great help we've been. All we accomplished is we now have a new probably very unwanted member.

The ONLY way we can help people find the monsters they absolutly want (and it is beyond me why people would actively search out a monster) is with the subcodes. Seriously, you can't buy a computer without a burner anymore. And for those who aren't planning to get one soon, if they're willing to go out hunting for a disk (buying, renting, bothering friends and familly to see if they have it), I'm sure they're willing to find someone with a burner that could do it for them. The subcodes for the ? subs and 1 of each main breed is enough to get all of the monsters.

Some people who posted in here wrote it helped them. How? King952 and Tristan Ferris said they MIGHT use it. CHB said he used it to see if his collection had a Raiden, he would have found it eventually. Lao seems to have used it to hunt but is unspecific, but I'm sure subcodes would have been more useful. Hawkmoon's post is just so wrong... looking in the cd list and go hunting is the slowest way you could ever get a monster. If you have it on disk or found it on adventure, it's in your book. If not, get 2 monsters from your book and combine. Worst to come, burn.

By CHB on Friday, January 9, 2004 - 05:57 pm:

My point boils to this topic arising again down the line. As I said before, new CDs and DVDs come out every day, and yes, many new ranchers can post in the CD list to feel 'helpful' to the community, after they do that, and run out of CDs, they generally disappear, never to post again. Why? Because thats all they got to connect them to here, that is the only thing they can relate to. To have someone stay, they must be willing to do something that requires time, like a research, or fanfic, or something else to hold them here, something to put effort into, something to be proud of. Not just posting all of their CDs. Of course, its a great way to start, but not a way to hook people into wanting to stay. That is participation in greater things.

I understand the outreach part of this, which is why I would say that the rare list does stay. As I said, I hunted down a Raiden, because I unlocked it, I worked for it. I also went through my entire DVD collection that weekend, so it really wouldn't have mattered in the end, as PT said. However, had it still been locked, THEN I would have been curious as to the contents.

I'm not certain how many people would go out and rent something for the monster it would shrine, if not for the item itself, but I understand some do. But I also understand quantities and surplus, which is what the CD list will be eventually. I'm not sure how much bandwidth this site holds, but the CD list is the thing growing largest, fastest, with little to no deletion. Eventually, this site will be one big CD list, unless topics are locked, or deleted. One of the two, but I have to agree with PT in that something needs to be accomplished.

One exception, sub breeds don't transfer in MR4 like they did in MR2. This list might need some work, since primary breeds will be a lot harder to come by. Combining is still achievable, though, and thus other monsters can be added to your encyclopedia.

Lastly, I'd like to thank everyone for their undaunted maturity on this topic. I'm very grateful.

With that said, I'm not an amateur. I'm a Master.

By Nate Railsback on Sunday, January 11, 2004 - 10:28 pm:

By Lao on Sunday, January 11, 2004 - 11:55 pm:

Couple things:

PT sort of asked me to be more specific. I checked the list daily to watch for Phoenix discs, until I found one on expedition. I used the list to get a Jell off a disc that was already in my (wife's) collection. It's not that I'm not shrining. I'm just not marathon shrining. I go through about 15-20 every time a new ranch spot opens. Which isn't often.

In my mind, the "You should have a CD burner" argument is kind of snobbish. Many players have older computers. Many players are children. Many players don't have the resources, whether you're talking about time, money, or whatever, to get ahold of a computer with a CD burner and blank CDs. This doesn't make them lazy or amateurish.

Also, about the non-ranch/breeder improvement: Getting a Jell most certainly helped to improve my ranch. Among other things, it enabled me to fully clear Kawrea (Flight/Power/All searches)--more money for more foods/items/gadget switches. More chances for Stones, Tablets, and Combo items. Was it the only way to get this done? No. I could have waited for a Jell or Dukken stone. But sometimes all the patience in the world doesn't win you what you're looking for. (Ask me about the Wind Drum that I still don't have, after dozens of expeditions.) Is it somehow "professional" to refuse to use a CD list to get the monster I need, just because there's another way to get it, in the game?

Here's another example: Suppose I'm tricking out my ranch to have a number of different-level gadgets to handle my monsters at different ages. It's strongly to my advantage to reduce the number of skills that I'm developing. Of course, certain monsters lend themselves to this streamlining. Suppose I want to cut Int entirely off the ranch? This will strongly influence my choices from each of the Power and Flight groups. For instance, for flight monsters, there's no way I want a Phoenix. I could go for a Dragon, but a Beaclon would probably be best. (Funny story. I have 4 Beaclons in book. 2 from shrining. 2 from combination. 0 from adventure stones.) For the Power group, I probably want a Golem. In fact, if I play my cards right, I can cut Speed and Int out, which allows me to focus my gadgets even more affectively. Suddenly, the choise of which breed to ranch isn't necessarily a matter of personal preference, but of ranch efficiency and effectiveness.

So ironically, in the game where the CD list is arguably the most obsolete, using specific breeds strategically is arguably more important than ever--which may make the CD list more important than ever.

Anyway, so, yeah, and stuff.

By catsgodot on Wednesday, January 14, 2004 - 11:39 pm:

It seems a lot of known folks are posting here, so why
shouldn't I?

In a nutshell: a CD/DVD database is invaluable. Not
everyone is going to be able to create CDs to get that one
monster they want. (Having pioneered the research, I can
assure you of that). It's usually easier to say, "Hey, I have
that CD / My buddy has that CD / I think I can get that at
my used music store!" than to set up CopyCD.

Me: I'm a casual player. I find that one subbreed, and I
want to play it. I don't care if it gets killed in battle and
never leaves E class. As long as I can explore it, get a feel
for raising it, I'm cool. And usually it's easier for me to
browse a CD DB and find it than to burn my own.
ESPECIALLY considering how much more diversified MR4 is
now with its shrining.

(Ironically enough, that's why I stopped by tonight--to find
a CD/DVD to catch a critter I haven't shrined yet)

Kalach: What's to stop you from hosting a database
yourself? For all the reasons Lisa listed above (and probably
more some), I haven't. Yes, I could whip together a quick
FileMaker DB and host a site. (It doesn't take a software
developer to do so.) Why haven't I? Let's start by asking
folks when they last saw me... But anyway, there's no rules
to keep you from hosting yours independently. There's
more than one MR site in existance, and certainly more than
one CD/DVD DB. In this field, the more the merrier.

--Cats, ever neverbeing.

ps: Doc Shock: if I don't see you soon, I need to thank
you--it's a long story, and the reason you haven't seen me
in the last week or two--but I really can't thank you
enough!

By Kalach on Thursday, January 15, 2004 - 06:30 am:

I was only interested if I thought that there was going to be people who wanted to run with the idea. Sound like they're not here, so I'm not worried about it.

By Hawkmoon on Friday, January 16, 2004 - 06:36 pm:

By Infernus on Friday, January 16, 2004 - 07:31 pm:

Okay, I have no idea what you meant by "Where you think along those lines". You say it helps you learn things about people...sure, but only a bit...maybe. What I meant by "categorize" is to put into a category of place in society...you know, teenager, drug user(some people are), etc. Or, it could mean "Oh this person must be very quiet", when in reality, that person may be very loud. What I basically said there is that just because you know what music they listen to, doesn't mean you know anything about them.

I have nothing against going through CD/DVD's, and never said I did, actually, if you read point 2(wow, reading, what a new concept), I actually suggest that maybe, just maybe, you'll want to go through your own CD/DVD's eventually. I do that very thing myself. It's just that from my point of view, the list at MRM serves no purpose.
